items.title: 1956: Official opening of refurbished Nulsen Haven.
23 September 1954
items.description: The Daily News article "A Father Speaks Up for Some the World Forgets" published.

items.title: 8 October 1954
items.description: Agreement to form the Mentally Incurable Children's Association (MICA) and election of office bearers, including inaugural President William R Burns.

items.title: 9 August 1955
items.description: "Dear Brutus" at 517 Great Eastern Highway, Redcliffe purchased as the first home for MICA.

items.title: 7 October 1956
items.description: The refurbished "Nulsen Haven" officially opened by Premier A R G Hawke, and Minister for Health Emil Nulsen.

items.title: September 1957
items.description: The first Women's Radio Service Club meeting held in Bunbury. Perth members later renamed themselves the "Wandana Club".

items.title: 21 November 1965
items.description: "Wedderburn" new Nulsen Haven hostel officially opened by Minister for Health the Hon G C McKinnon.
Nulsen Ladies' Auxiliary Opportunity Shoppe opens in Victoria Park.
Jane Marshall, radio presenter who spoke with family who had to leave call to tend to her child.
Commencement of resident training at Nulsen, leading an evolution in disability services.
Ms Jill Bennett appointed Matron to usher in a new era.

additionalContent.description: 1973: Commencement of resident training at Nulsen, leading an evolution in disability services.

items.title: May 1977
items.description: Nulsen commences its first May campaign, raising funds and publicity. A year later, the "horse raffle" became a major part of the May campaign for 14 years.

items.title: The Early 80's
items.description: Listen to Ea anim laboris sit laborum pariatur consectetur nostrud id aliquip cupidatat esse dolor do qui duis.
“Normalisation” formally adopted at Nulsen based on standards and principles embodied in report submitted by the Murdoch Group.

items.title: 2 October 1983
items.description: MICA formally becomes Nulsen Haven Association Inc (for the training and care of severely and profoundly Intellectually Handicapped People).

items.title: January 1987
items.description: Six residents from urgent wait list move into experimental group home at Yorna Road, Kalamunda.

items.title: July 1987
items.description: Landmark legislation Disability Services Act 1986 comes into effect.

items.title: April 1988
items.description: Implementation of 10-year Transition Plan commences with key components - the Personal Future Planning process, PASSING workshops and in-service workshops aimed at providing “information and inspiration”.

items.title: 8 May 1989
items.description: The first two residents move into their own home in the community, in Willetton.

items.title: May 1989
items.description: Independent Living Services commences, with around 40 community activities in place within 2 years.

items.title: Early 90's
items.description: Listen to Ea anim laboris sit laborum pariatur consectetur nostrud id aliquip cupidatat esse dolor do qui duis.
